conclusion: To determine the ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for particles A and B during their deceleration phases, analyze the slopes of the velocity-time graph.
For particle A, the deceleration phase occurs from t = t0 to t = 2t0.
For particle B, the deceleration phase occurs from t = 5t0 to t = 6t0.
Calculate acceleration for particle A: Initial velocity at t = t0 is 2v0, final velocity at t = 2t0 is 0, time interval is t0.
Acceleration a_A is given by the change in velocity over the change in time: a_A = (0 - 2v0) / t0 = -2v0 / t0.
The magnitude of acceleration for A is 2v0 / t0.
Calculate acceleration for particle B: Initial velocity at t = 5t0 is v0, final velocity at t = 6t0 is 0, time interval is t0.
Acceleration a_B is given by the change in velocity over the change in time: a_B = (0 - v0) / t0 = -v0 / t0.
The magnitude of acceleration for B is v0 / t0.
Determine the ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration: Ratio = (2v0 / t0) / (v0 / t0) = 2.
The ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for A and B during their deceleration phases is 2:1.
